document.docTitle: Laonice mediterranea Sikorski, Nygren & Rousou 2021, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Laonice bahusiensis complex (Annelida: Spionidae) with a description of three new species

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Laonice bahusiensis :
Dağli et al . 2011: 54–57
, fig. 5.
Çinar et al. 2012: 1462
;
2014: 746
.
Çinar & Dağli 2013: 923
. Not Söder- ström 1920.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
CYPRUS , off Cape Greco (Cavo Grekko), 34.9703°N , 34.0839°E ,
31 m
, shell fragments, fine sand
.

Type material.
MOM INV-0022696 (
holotype
)
,
INV-0022697 , 0022700–0022705 ( 20 paratypes )
;
MIMB 39040 ( 1 paratype )
, 40463 ( 1 paratype ), 40464 ( 1 paratype );
MNCNM 16.01 /18567–18569 ( 14 paratypes )
.
Adult morphology. Holotype largest complete specimen 38 mm long, 0.83 mm wide for 105 chaetigers. Pigmentation absent on body and palps.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14. Maps showing records of
Laonice bahusiensis
complex species in the Mediterranean (see Tables 1, S3–S4). A, Laonice grimaldii
n. sp .
: red star—type locality: Livorno, Ligurian Sea, Italy; green triangles—specimens sequenced in the present study; yellow circles—specimens identified based on the morphology only. B,
Laonice mediterranea
n. sp.
: red star—type locality: Levantine Sea, Cave Greco (Cavo Grekko), Cyprus; green triangles—specimens sequenced in the present study; yellow circles—specimens identified based on the morphology only; turquoise circles—adults identified based on the morphology by other authors and not verified in the present study.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Prostomium triangular, anteriorly wide, broadly rounded, occasionally truncate to slightly concave, fused with fronto-lateral margin of peristomium ( Figs 15C, G , 16A ), posteriorly extending over 33 chaetigers (to end of chaetiger 30 in holotype ) as a well-developed narrow caruncle, shorter in smaller individuals ( Fig. 17A ). Nuchal organs U-shaped ciliary bands on sides of caruncle ( Figs 15C, D , 16A ). Length of nuchal organs was strongly correlated with individual number of branchiate chaetigers ( Fig. 17C, r
2
= 0.8124, n = 20). Occipital antenna usually short ( Figs 15C, G , 16B ), occasionally comparatively long ( Fig. 16A ). Two pairs of red eyes (appearing almost black in formalin-fixed specimens) usually present, comprising one pair of very large median eyes and one pair of small lateral eyes situated anteriorly and either in front of median eyes ( Fig. 16A ) or set wider apart, occasionally between prostomium and peristomium and therefore not visible in dorsal view ( Fig. 15C, G ). Median eyes often occupying entire posterior part of prostomium in front of occipital antenna ( Figs 15C , 16A ). Lateral eyes situated well apart from median eyes ( Fig. 16A ). Only in holotype median eyes appearing as two narrow oblique dark stripes surrounded by residual pigment similar in size and shape to big eyes in other specimens, suggesting that original big eyes faded. Palps missing in all specimens examined.

Lateral interneuropodial pouches from chaetigers 7–27 (from chaetiger 15 in holotype ) to end of body. Anterior start of pouches was strongly correlated with individual number of branchiate chaetigers ( Fig. 18D, r
2
= 0.7681, n = 20).

Sabre chaetae in neuropodia from chaetigers 11–16 (from chaetiger 15 in holotype ), from more anterior chaetigers in small individuals ( Fig. 17B ), 1–2 in a tuft; chaetae with weak granulation on shaft, up to twice as long as hooks. Anterior start of sabre chaetae was moderately correlated with individual number of branchiate chaetigers ( Fig. 17D, r
2
= 0.4822, n = 20).

Hooded hooks in neuropodia from chaetigers 18–33 (from chaetiger 28 in holotype ), from more anterior chaetigers in small individuals ( Fig. 17B ), up to nine in a series, accompanied by inferior sabre chaetae and alternating capillaries throughout body. Hooks quadridentate, with one pair of upper teeth and single superior median tooth above main fang ( Fig. 16C ), or quinquedentate, with one pair of superior teeth instead of single superior tooth; shaft slightly curved. Anterior start of hooks was strongly correlated with individual number of branchiate chaetigers ( Fig. 17D, r
2
= 0.7014, n = 20).
Digestive tract without gizzard-like structure.

Remarks. The specimens herein referred to
L. mediterranea
n. sp.
had earlier been identified as
L. bahusiensis
(
Dağli et al . 2011
;
Çinar et al. 2012
, 2014 ; Çinar & Dağli 2013 ). However, in
L. bahusiensis
nuchal organs terminate 0–10 chaetigers before the last branchiate chaetiger ( Fig. 19A ), and dorsal transverse crests first appear on a chaetiger after the end of nuchal organs, whereas in
L. mediterranea
n. sp.
nuchal organs usually extend beyond the last branchiate chaetiger ( Figs 15D , 19B ), and dorsal transverse crests first appear 1–4 chaetigers before the end of nuchal organs ( Fig. 15D ).

;

/18569; G,

.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 16.
Laonice mediterranea
n. sp.
adult morphology. A, anterior end, dorsal view. B, anterior end, left lateral view. C, neuropodial hooded hook. A—MOM INV-0022701; B—MOM INV-0022696 (holotype); C—MNCNM 16.01/18567. Scale bars: A, B = 300 µm; C = 5 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Laonice mediterranea
n. sp.
appears most similar to
L. irinae
n. sp.
(see above) from North European waters, but can be distinguished from the latter by the size of the median eyes and the shape of notopodial postchaetal lamellae on anterior chaetigers. In
L. irinae
n. sp.
the ratio of length of the prostomium in front of median eyes ( l 1 ) to the length of median eyes ( l 2 ) is always more than 2.5, and the acute peaks on upper tips of notopodial postchaetal lamellae are strictly terminal on the ten anterior chaetigers, whereas in
L. mediterranea
n. sp.
the ratio of the length of the prostomium in front of the median eyes ( l 1 ) to the length of the median eyes ( l 2 ) is less than 2.3. Acute peaks on the upper tips of notopodial postchaetal lamellae, if present, in
L. mediterranea
are shifted onto the lateral margin from chaetigers 5–6 to chaetigers 8–9, unlike lamellae on at least ten anterior chaetigers with terminal acute peaks on upper tips in
L. irinae
.

In the Mediterranean Sea,
L. mediterranea
n. sp.
co-occurs with
L. grimaldii
n. sp.
( Fig. 14 ). The adults look similar but can be distinguished by the Br-NO values, which vary from -4 to 1 in the former and from 2 to 12 in the latter species ( Fig. 19B ). Moreover, the adults of
L. mediterranea
n. sp.
have very large median eyes usually occupying the entire posterior part of the prostomium until the occipital antenna ( Fig. 15C ), whereas in the adults of
L. grimaldii
n. sp.
median eyes appear as transverse bars or oblong oval spots ( Fig. 10A ).
Etymology. The species name refers to its wide distribution and the type locality in the Mediterranean Sea.
Distribution. Mediterranean Sea ( Fig. 14B ). At 3–71 m depth.
